question: Which bony landmark is palpated to locate the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS)?
short_explanation: The PSIS lies beneath the dimples of the lower back.
long_explanation: The PSIS can be found by palpating medially and slightly inferior to the iliac crest, where dimples are visible on many individuals.
clinical_application: Identifying the PSIS is key for sacral alignment, lumbar assessment, and low back pain evaluation.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which structure is typically palpated just lateral to the cervical spinous processes?
short_explanation: The transverse processes of C1–C7 are lateral to the spinous processes.
long_explanation: C7 is easily located due to its prominent spinous process. Transverse processes lie laterally and can be palpated to assess cervical mobility.
clinical_application: Palpating these structures aids in identifying restricted motion, asymmetry, or vertebral misalignment.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

correctAnswer: Midpoint between greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity
question: Which landmark is commonly used to locate the sciatic nerve in gluteal palpation?
options: Midpoint between greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity
short_explanation: The sciatic nerve lies between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity.
long_explanation: To locate the sciatic nerve, draw an imaginary line between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity. Palpation near the midpoint of this line may elicit nerve sensitivity.
clinical_application: Precise palpation avoids nerve compression and guides effective gluteal massage.
source_reference: Muscolino's Clinical Anatomy for Manual Therapists

question: Where is the sternocleidomastoid muscle most easily palpated?
short_explanation: It is located between the mastoid process and the sternum/clavicle.
long_explanation: The SCM can be palpated when the client rotates their head to the side and slightly lifts it. The muscle forms a diagonal band on the neck from mastoid to clavicle/sternum.
clinical_application: Palpating the SCM is helpful for treating tension headaches and postural imbalance.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which landmark is essential for locating the medial border of the scapula?
short_explanation: The vertebral border of the scapula lies closest to the spine.
long_explanation: The medial (vertebral) border of the scapula is palpated by drawing fingers along the inner edge of the scapula as the arm is moved across the body or lifted.
clinical_application: Helps assess shoulder blade motion and scapular winging in posture evaluations.

correctAnswer: Medial to the biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa
question: Which anatomical landmark is most useful when locating the brachial artery for pulse assessment?
options: Medial to the biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa
short_explanation: The brachial artery runs medial to the biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa.
long_explanation: To locate the brachial pulse, palpate medial to the biceps tendon in the anterior elbow (antecubital fossa). This area is commonly used for blood pressure measurement.
clinical_application: Accurate palpation of the brachial artery aids in assessing circulation and selecting massage techniques for the upper limb.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which bony landmark helps identify the border between the upper trapezius and levator scapulae?
short_explanation: The superior angle of the scapula marks this transition.
long_explanation: The superior angle of the scapula is the insertion point of levator scapulae and can be palpated to assess tension differences with the trapezius.
clinical_application: Helps differentiate muscular tension sources in neck and shoulder complaints.

question: To palpate the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii, where should the therapist begin?
short_explanation: Start in the intertubercular groove of the humerus.
long_explanation: The long head of the biceps brachii runs through the intertubercular groove. With slight external rotation of the arm, the tendon becomes palpable between the greater and lesser tubercles.
clinical_application: Accurate palpation helps assess biceps tendonitis or shoulder instability.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which bony prominence is felt just behind the ear and serves as an attachment site for several muscles?
short_explanation: The mastoid process is palpable behind the ear.
long_explanation: The mastoid process of the temporal bone is a rounded projection behind the ear. It serves as an attachment for the sternocleidomastoid, splenius capitis, and other muscles.
clinical_application: Palpation helps assess neck muscle tension and guide craniosacral techniques.

correctAnswer: Medial and inferior to the ASIS
question: Which landmark helps guide palpation of the iliopsoas muscle in the lower abdomen?
options: Medial and inferior to the ASIS
short_explanation: The iliopsoas lies deep to the ASIS and inguinal ligament.
long_explanation: To palpate the iliopsoas, locate the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and move slightly medial and inferior beneath the inguinal ligament. This region requires caution due to nearby vascular structures.
clinical_application: Palpation of the iliopsoas can assist in assessing hip flexor tightness or psoas syndrome.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.
